abstract: Scientists are now turning to a more nuanced understanding of social media and its impact on children. Many have started to approach social media as an integral, if risky, part of adolescence, perhaps not unlike driving.
lead_paragraph: Much of the early research - and many of the early pronouncements - on social media seemed calculated to make parents terrified of an emerging technology that many of them did not understand as well as their children did, writes Perri Klass, in the 18 and Under column in the online Health section of The New York Times. Scientists are now turning to a more nuanced understanding of this new world. Many have started to approach social media as an integral, if risky, part of adolescence, perhaps not unlike driving. headline.main: Seeing Social Media More as Portal Than as Pitfall
